awd_titl_txt: Institutional Transformation: Cultivating an ethical STEM culture through an integrated undergraduate general education
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will study the implementation and effectiveness of a university wide ethical reasoning curriculum. The project will identify and assess the culture of ethics education that emerges from "Pathways to General Education" at Virginia Tech. The project will do a systematic analysis of institutional transformation. It will focus on the culture of STEM ethics by tracing the implementation of ethical reasoning into a new general education curriculum.  The research will evaluate the transferability of this approach to other institutions.   The project will contribute to broadening students' expertise beyond their field of study and to provide competencies that will transfer to the workplace. Summer institutes, webinars, on-line training modules and workshops will be developed for faculty to promote ethical considerations in teaching and doing STEM. The findings of this project will be of interest to faculty members, students, university administrators and businesses. 

The project will include multi-pronged evaluations of the efficacy of a new curriculum program at Virginia Tech. It will understand the dynamics of the individual, collective, and institutional processes evident in their implementation; and test the overall utility of the ABCD theory of change as employed in this transformation effort.  There are four categories of anticipated impacts from this project: 1) evaluation for direct improvement in faculty ethics teaching competency, 2) evaluation of students' ethics learning competency, 3) estimation of changes to ethical climate in an R1 STEM focused university, and 4) dissemination of findings and best practices from this project's research to other institutions. The project will collect qualitative and quantitative data through interviews, surveys and participant observation.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to systematically analyze the institutional transformation required to establish a culture of STEM ethics at Virginia Tech (VT) through the implementation of the Pathways curriculum. The research assessed the efficacy of new programs, the dynamics of individual and institutional processes, and the utility of the ABCD theory of change in guiding this transformation. Additionally, the project explored strategies for collaborative extension of successful practices to other institutions and multi-institutional exercises.

The project has several significant outcomes, beginning with faculty perceptions of the Pathways model. Through interviews and focus groups, faculty members highlighted both the utility and challenges associated with its implementation. These discussions revealed an increased awareness of ethical and global considerations in STEM education and research. Faculty also developed innovative strategies to integrate these considerations into general education courses, laying a strong foundation for sustained cultural change.

In terms of student outcomes, assessments demonstrated substantial gains in ethical and cross-cultural competencies among students exposed to the Pathways curriculum, compared to those following traditional general education approaches. This impact was particularly notable among non-STEM majors, whose technical fluency and ethical awareness improved significantly, underscoring the curriculum’s effectiveness in engaging diverse undergraduate populations.

At the university level, aggregated data pointed to a measurable shift in the ethical climate at VT. This transformation was marked by increased faculty engagement in ethics-focused professional development and the integration of ethical considerations into both teaching and research. These changes signaled a broader institutional commitment to graduating ethically competent STEM professionals.

The project’s influence extended beyond VT through the development and piloting of collaborative tools, such as summer institutes, webinars, and online training modules. These resources facilitated the dissemination of best practices and transformative strategies to affiliate institutions. By incorporating feedback and enabling adaptations to diverse educational contexts, the project effectively set the stage for broader cultural shifts in STEM ethics education.

The broader impacts of this project are wide-ranging and significant. By focusing on engaging STEM learning experiences in general education courses, the initiative has reached all undergraduates, thereby increasing STEM literacy across diverse student populations. This approach has also encouraged greater participation in STEM-related minors, with a particular emphasis on including traditionally underrepresented groups. Furthermore, the integration of ethics and intercultural knowledge into STEM courses has prepared graduates with the critical competencies necessary to navigate a globally connected and ethically complex workforce. This has strengthened the alignment of STEM education with the demands of the modern professional landscape. The project has also empowered a new generation of STEM educators by involving undergraduate and graduate students in curriculum development. This hands-on experience with evidence-based teaching strategies ensures sustainability and continued improvement of educational advancements within STEM disciplines. Finally, the application of the ABCD theory of change has proven to be an effective framework for guiding institutional transformation. This model not only facilitated the successful implementation of the project at VT but also offers a replicable approach for other institutions seeking to cultivate cultures of ethical STEM education.

 This project has set the stage for continued ethical and cultural transformation at VT and beyond. By training faculty to incorporate ethics into teaching and research, the project has prompted lasting changes in faculty orientation toward ethical considerations. The dissemination of findings and best practices through international networks of scholars ensures the propagation of this model, amplifying its impact on higher education institutions globally. The integration of ethics into general education and STEM courses has positioned VT as a leader in cultivating ethically aware and globally competent graduates, fostering a more informed and equitable society.
